summary.text_en: Working under Ernest Rutherford, John Cockcroft and Ernest Walton built one of the first practical 'particle accelerators', the 'Cockcroft-Walton generator', which created a massive DC voltage (~700,000 Volts). In 1932, they used this machine to accelerate *protons* and fire them at a *lithium* target. They succeeded in 'splitting the atom': the lithium nucleus broke apart into two 'alpha particles' (helium nuclei). This was the first time in history an atom had been split by an *artificially accelerated* particle and the first experimental verification of Einstein's E=mcÂ².
key_points_en: First to 'Split the Atom' with *artificially* accelerated particles
Fired protons at lithium, producing helium
First experimental proof of Einstein's E=mcÂ²
Won the 1951 Nobel Prize in Physics

story.text_en: In the 1930s, the race was on to 'split the atom'. Rutherford, the 'father of the nucleus', believed they needed high-energy 'bullets' (particles) to crack it open. Cockcroft and Walton built a 'voltage multiplier' (a rival to the `van_de_graaff_generator_1929`) that could stack voltage up to enormous levels. They accelerated protons (hydrogen nuclei) and aimed them at a thin lithium target. On the other side, they placed a 'scintillation screen'. When they ran the experiment, they saw *tiny flashes of light* on the screen. These were the two alpha particles (helium) flying apart back-to-back. When they measured the *total energy* of these two helium particles, they found it was *greater* than the energy of the proton they shot in. This 'extra' energy *perfectly* matched the tiny amount of 'mass' that was *lost* in the reactionâ€”a perfect proof of Einstein's E=mcÂ².

fun_facts.text_en: This was the first 'artificial' nuclear fission in human history.
They won the Nobel Prize in Physics for this work in 1951, almost 20 years after the experiment.
Their 'Cockcroft-Walton generator' design was so successful that it is *still* used today in particle accelerators (like at CERN) as a 'pre-accelerator' stage.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine trying to shoot a 'BB pellet' (a proton) at a 'wafer cookie' (a lithium atom).
Cockcroft and Walton were the first to accelerate that 'BB' so fast that it didn't just punch a holeâ€”it *shattered* the 'cookie' into *two new pieces* (two helium atoms).
The magic was, when they 'weighed' the energy of those two new pieces, they found they had *more energy* than the original proton and cookie combined! This 'extra' energy was exactly the amount *mass* that had been 'lost' in the crash, perfectly proving Einstein's (`einstein_special_relativity_1905`) E=mcÂ².

applications.text_en: The 'Cockcroft-Walton generator' (or 'voltage multiplier') is still a standard engineering design used in X-ray machines, televisions, and particle accelerators to generate high voltage.

impact.text_en: Cockcroft and Walton's experiment (along with the `van_de_graaff_generator_1929`) was the starting gun for the 'Nuclear Age'. It marked the moment physics shifted from *observing* nature to *changing* it. By being the first to 'split' the atom, they unleashed 'nuclear energy' and provided the initial experimental basis that would lead to the Manhattan Project and the age of nuclear power 10 years later.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ernest Rutherford (their mentor, who discovered the nucleus and set the challenge to 'split it')
Einstein (his E=mcÂ² formula was what they were trying to experimentally verify)
Van de Graaff (his generator was the 'competing design' for a DC particle accelerator)

influenced.contribution_en: Ernest Lawrence (his 'Cyclotron' was an alternative, more powerful accelerator design that soon surpassed it)
The Manhattan Project (all 'nuclear fission' research stems from this first artificial splitting of the atom)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Cockcroft and Walton built an 'artificial volcano' (an accelerator) and used it to 'split' the atom for the first time, unleashing the energy locked inside mass.

quiz.question_en: The 1932 Cockcroft-Walton experiment was the first *experimental* verification of which famous *theoretical* equation?
quiz.explanation_en: They measured the energy of the particles *after* the reaction (two helium) and found it was *greater* than the energy of the particle *before* (one proton). This 'new' energy perfectly matched the tiny amount of *mass* that was 'lost' in the reaction. It was the first experimental proof of E=mcÂ².
